description:
Candidatus Rickettsia colombianensi is a proposed species of bacteria within the genus Rickettsia. It is an obligate intracellular bacterium, meaning it can only replicate and survive within the living cells of a host organism.

Candidatus Rickettsia colombianensi was first discovered and proposed in Colombia, South America, hence the name "colombianensi." It is closely related to other Rickettsia species that are known to cause various tick-borne diseases in humans and animals.

The bacterium is typically found within the cells of ticks, which can act as vectors, transmitting the pathogen to other hosts, such as humans and animals, through their bites. Infection with Candidatus Rickettsia colombianensi may lead to the development of a tick-borne illness, although the specific clinical manifestations and disease characteristics are still under investigation.

Further research is needed to fully understand the biology, epidemiology, and potential public health significance of this proposed Rickettsia species, as it continues to be studied and characterized by the scientific community.
